title: Questionable advice: My boss says we don’t need any engineering managers. Is he right?
section: Why managers exist? Why org structures exist?
text:
Why managers exist? Why org structures exist?
How does a bad org structure look like? Rank (position in a hierarchy) is used as a tool of oppression. Information hoarding, playing dominance games (politics). Decisions are made based on rank.
Hierarchy is a property of self-organizing systems.

A system is “a network of interdependent components that work together to try to accomplish a common aim.” – W. Edward Deming.

A subsystem is a collection of elements with a smaller aim inside a larger system. The sybsystems always work to support the needs of the larger system; if the sybsystem instead optimizes for its own best interest, the whole system can fail.
A system is self-organizing if it has the ability to make itself more complex, by diversifying, adapting, and improving itself. As systems self-organize and their complexity increases, they tend to generate hierarchy – an arrangement of systems and subsystems. In a stable, resilient and efficient system, sybsystems can largely take care of themselves, regulate themselves, and serve the needs of the larger system, while the larger system coordinates between subsystems and helps them perform better. Hierarchy minimizes the costs of coordination and reduces the amount of information that any given part of the system has to keep track of, preventing information overload. Information transfer and relationships withing a sybsystem are more more dense and have fewer delays than information transfer or relationshions between subsystems.
A manager’s job is to coordinate between teams and help their team perform better.
Software product development organizations are socio-technical systems, but the separation between “socio/people” and “technical/engineering” is never clean. Need for “glue work”.
Tasks that need to be done by any functional engineering org besides writing code:

Recruiting: networking, interviewing, writing job descriptions and career ladders.
Project management: managing stakeholders, prioritizing backlog, estimating size and scope.
Running team meetings: 1x1s (growth feedback), retrospectives, writing reviews, representing the teams’s needs.
Architecture, code reviews, capturing DORA and productivity metrics, managing burnout.

title: Questionable advice: My boss says we don’t need any engineering managers. Is he right?
section: Engineering managers are a useful abstraction.
text:
Engineering managers are a useful abstraction.
One of the primary benefits of hierarchy is to reduce information overload. Engineering labor takes concentration and focus. Context switching is expensive. Management labor consist of context switching every hour or so, and being available for interruptions throughtout the day. Engineering calendar and management calendar do not coexist well.
It isn’t up to managers to do all the glue work, but it is a manager’s job to make sure that everything that needs to get done, does gets done (requires providing necessary resources to people who do the actual work).
An engineer is responsible for the software she develops, deploys, and maintains. A manager is responsible for her team and the organization as a whole.
In natural hierarchies, we look up for purpose and down for function. The above makes a complicated argument for why we need engineering managers.
The simpler argument is that most engineering orgs have engineering managers. It is something that many smart people had to spend considerable time thinking about. It may sound “boring”, but actually it is like with “choosing boring technology” which means “the capabilities and failure conditions are well understood”.
When there is no explicit structure or hierarchy, the result is not freedom and egalitarianism (see The Tyranny of Structureless). Such orgs tend to be chaotic, fragile and frustrating.
No EMs because of management overhead (because managers are not supposed to do tech work) is a flawed argument. Mostly because “productivity” does not equate “lines of code”.

title: Org signalling
text:
Just like people, organizations use signalling to communicate with the rest of the world. SEC filing, branding campaigns, industry awards are obvious mechanisms. Certifications like ISO 9001 are useful for getting contractual agreements. There are also more subtle signals. For example B-corp certification means that a for-profit organization puts social sustainability above profit, while worldblue membership signals a cultural shift from traditional command-and-control to a more progressive organization.
But there are also organizations that don’t bother with certifications and branding. They just focus on doing good work and leave signalling to word-of-mouth. Corporate Rebels and their bucketlist are currently the best source of information on such organizations. Happy to see Odd-e appearing in the list.

title: Trick or Treatment? Alternative Medicine on Trial
text:
General chapter on what is evidence-based medicine using bloodletting as a historic example of how long established treatment methods can be challenged. Bloodletting was already used in ancient Greece and continued to be widely used until 1850’s as a treatment option to many conditions. In 1799 George_Washington got pneumonia and died supposedly from extensive bloodletting. In the same year there was probably the first famous court case about medical malpractice between Benjamin Rush and William Cobbett. Rush was a rather famous and established doctor and politician and easily won the case.
At that time the idea of conducting clinical trials to establish the efficiency of treatment was not yet accepted by the medical establishment. However, first attempts to conduct such trials to have been performed by James Lind in 1747 in an attempt to establish the treatment for scurvy. Scurvy was a disease that affected a large number of sailors (many more death due to scurvy than anything else including war injuries). Lind isolated 12 sailors, separated them in 6 pairs, gave similar diet, but different treatments. He correctly observed that citrus fruit improved patients condition. The link to vitamin C was already known at that time, but wasn’t widely accepted. Lind failed to publish his results. In 1780 Gilbert Blane repeated Lind’s experiment involving many more subjects and managed to convince the British navy to make mandatory use of lime juice to prevent scurvy (hence “limey”).
The first trial that questioned the efficiency of bloodletting was supposedly conducted by Alexander Lesassier Hamilton in 1809. He introduced random patient assignment between 3 doctors and showed that the mortality rates were much lower in the two groups where bloodletting wasn’t used. He failed to publish and disseminate his results. It was Pierre Charles Louis, a French physician, who reconfirmed inefficiency of bloodletting for treatment of fevers in 1828. His “numerical method” was strongly opposed by the medical community.
Other examples of how evidence was used to advance medical practice are the stories of Florence Nightingale, who demonstrated the importance of hygiene in military hospitals during Crimean war (1853-1856) using mortality statistics, and the British Doctors Study by Hill and Doll in the early 1950’s that demonstrated the link between smoking and lung cancer (first prospective cohort study, used doctors as subjects in order to get a more homogeneous sample population).

Evidence based medicine can be used to decide what works, what does not work, efficiency of preventive methods, and what causes the disease.


Evidence based medicine is the conscientious, explicit, and judicious use of current best evidence in making decisions about the care of individual patients. – David Sackett

Placebos
Placebo effect was probably recognized very early.
John Haygarth conducted a trial in 1799 on the efficiency of “Perkins’ tractors” and demonstrated that fake “tractors” were as efficient as the originals and concluded that “powerful influence upon diseases is produced by mere imagination”. He also recognized that placebo plays a role in genuine medicine as well as is dependent on factors such as doctor’s reputation, cost of the treatment, novelty…

Lines in the sand

People today will mostly focus on the points of connection, the nodes of interest like stars in the sky. But the real understanding comes in the spaces in between, in the relational forces that connect and move the points.


Systems are heterarchical – composed of equal parts interacting together. Imposing a hierarchical model of top-down control can only destroy them. Healthy interventions can only be made by free agents within a complex system.


On learning another culture (cultural humility): 1) Check your ego and motives, 2) You don’t need to be an expert to understand the knowledge process of people from other cultures and enter into dialogues with them (but you need to show respect), 3) Making yourself an expert in another culture is not always appreciated by the members of that culture.


It is difficult to relinquish the illusions of power and delusions of exceptionalism that come with privilege. But it is strangely liberating to realise your true status as a single node in a cooperative network.


Sustainable systems cannot function without the full autonomy and unique expression of each independent part of the interdependent whole.


Sustainability agents have a few simple operating guidelines, or network protocols, or rules if you like – connect, diversify, interact and adapt.


An agent that is truly adaptive and changing is open to sudden eruptions of transformation.


Not all strange attractors are benevolent (narcissist).


Adolescent cultures always ask the same three questions. Why are we here? How should we live? What will happen when we die?

There are at least four parts to your spirit from an Aboriginal point of view: your higher self (superego), ancestral spirit, living spirit and shadow spirit… Your shadow spirit is that part of you that wants things you don’t need, makes you think you’re better than other people and above the land. If the rest of your spirit is not clear and in balance, it gets away from you, causing conflict and destruction. You gossip behind people’s backs, spread uncertainty, deliver judgments, upset people, take more than you need and accumulate goods without sharing. It makes you a competitor instead of a human being.

There needs to be an interaction between abstract (spirit) and concrete (physical) worlds of knowledge for this kind of complexity to develop fully.


Without closing the loop between abstract knowledge and reality, and without making connections between different ideas and areas of knowledge, true learning cannot occur.

title: Famous programmers who pair program
section: P: Give me a few know examples of famous technologists who frequently use pair programming in their daily work.
text:
P: Give me a few know examples of famous technologists who frequently use pair programming in their daily work.
Finding famous technologists who daily practice pair programming is rare because many move into management or architectural roles. However, there are a few legendary examples of “hands-on” titans who used it to build some of the most critical software in history, as well as the methodology creators who evangelized it.

1. The Most Famous Duo: Jeff Dean and Sanjay Ghemawat
These two are arguably the most effective pair programmers in the history of Silicon Valley. They are Senior Fellows at Google (the highest technical level) and are responsible for building the foundational systems of the modern internet: MapReduce, BigTable, Spanner, and LevelDB.

How they worked: For years, they worked at the same computer, sharing a keyboard and monitor. They would often finish each other’s sentences and code.
The “Chuck Norris” Fact: There is a famous internal joke at Google that “Jeff Dean’s compiler warns him about errors,” but in reality, his “compiler” was often Sanjay sitting next to him.
Why it mattered: Their pairing allowed them to build massive, complex distributed systems that were exceptionally bug-free and efficient because they were constantly reviewing each other’s logic in real-time.



2. The Creator: Kent Beck
Kent Beck is the father of Extreme Programming (XP), the software methodology that popularized pair programming in the 1990s. He is also the creator of JUnit and Test Driven Development (TDD).

His Daily Habit: While he moves between roles (Meta, Gusto, etc.), he treats pair programming as a discipline rather than a suggestion. He famously stated that for complex or production-critical code, he does not work alone.
The Philosophy: He argues that “code reviews” are too late in the process. Pairing is a continuous, real-time code review that prevents bad design decisions before they are written.



3. The Craftsman: Robert C. Martin (“Uncle Bob”)
A signatory of the Agile Manifesto and author of Clean Code, Uncle Bob is a vocal advocate for professionalism in coding, which he believes often requires pairing.

His Approach: He advocates for pairing particularly when solving “deep” problems or training junior developers. He views it as a transfer of professional standards—teaching not just what to code, but how to think about code.
The “Ping Pong” Method: He frequently demonstrates and uses “Ping Pong Pairing,” where one person writes a failing test (TDD), passes the keyboard to the other to make it pass, who then writes the next failing test, and passes it back.



4. The Thought Leader: Martin Fowler
As a Chief Scientist at ThoughtWorks and a prolific author (Refactoring, Patterns of Enterprise Application Architecture), Fowler has institutionalized pair programming at an organizational level.

Daily Work: While he writes more prose than code these days, his daily work involves “pairing” on technical articles and architectural designs. He advocates that pairing is just as effective for writing documentation and design specs as it is for code.
Influence: Under his technical guidance, companies like ThoughtWorks require consultants to pair program 100% of the time, proving it works at scale in daily enterprise work.



Summary: Why they do it
These technologists don’t pair program because they are “slow” or need help. They do it because:

Immediate Feedback: Bugs are caught in seconds, not days.
Focus: It is much harder to procrastinate or check Twitter when someone is watching you code.
Bus Factor: No single person “owns” the code; the knowledge is shared instantly.

title: Famous programmers who pair program
section: P: What about creators of UNIX and C programming language?
text:
P: What about creators of UNIX and C programming language?
Yes, Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie are arguably the “original” pair programmers, long before the term existed.
While they didn’t have a formal “Agile” manifesto, their working style at Bell Labs in the late 1960s and 70s is exactly what modern pair programming aims to emulate.

The “Proto-Pairing” of Thompson and Ritchie
They are the ultimate example of informal, high-bandwidth collaboration.

The Hardware Constraint: In the early days, they were working on a PDP-7 and later a PDP-11. These were massive machines but often had limited terminals. It was physically natural to sit side-by-side at the teletype to debug the kernel or language features together.
The Workflow: Thompson (the rapid-fire hacker) would often write the initial implementation of a UNIX feature, and Ritchie (the theoretician and language designer) would refine the C language to support it, often in the same room, effectively “pairing” on the architecture of the system.
The “Rubber Duck” Effect: They served as each other’s immediate feedback loop. If Thompson hit a roadblock in the OS, Ritchie was there to adjust the C compiler to fix it, and vice versa. This tight loop is why UNIX and C fit together so perfectly—they evolved simultaneously in the same room.



Other Historical Examples of “De Facto” Pairing
Before it was a named methodology, many early computing breakthroughs came from duos who shared a brain (and often a keyboard):

Bill Gates and Paul Allen (Microsoft Basic): In the famous “crunch mode” to write the BASIC interpreter for the Altair 8800, they worked non-stop for weeks. One would write the assembly code while the other verified the logic and manually calculated memory addresses (since they had no assembler). This was “Driver-Navigator” pairing in its rawest form.
Steve Wozniak and Steve Jobs (Breakout): While Wozniak was the primary engineer, the development of the arcade game Breakout for Atari involved Jobs staying up four nights straight with Wozniak. Jobs (who couldn’t design circuits) acted as the “Navigator/Product Owner,” reviewing the game mechanics and motivating Wozniak to reduce the chip count, while Wozniak (“The Driver”) executed the design.



Why this matters
The creators of UNIX and C prove that pair programming isn’t just a training tool for juniors; it is a discovery tool for masters. When two experts pair, they don’t just write code faster—they invent entirely new paradigms (like the pipe | operator, which was debated and refined in that collaborative environment).

section: P: Who are famous technical coaches who teach and promote pair programming and TDD?
text:
P: Who are famous technical coaches who teach and promote pair programming and TDD?
Beyond the legendary creators, there is a vibrant community of “Technical Coaches”—professionals who literally make a living teaching teams how to pair program and practice Test Driven Development (TDD).
Here are the most famous technical coaches active today, each known for a specific “style” or contribution to the field.

1. The “Strong-Style” Specialist: Llewellyn Falco
Llewellyn is famous for defining Strong-Style Pairing, a specific technique designed to force collaboration and prevent the “Driver” (typist) from ignoring the “Navigator.”

His Golden Rule: “For an idea to go from your head into the computer, it must go through someone else’s hands.”
How it works: If you are the Navigator and you know exactly what to type, you cannot type it. You must verbally describe it to the Driver. If the Driver doesn’t understand, you don’t grab the keyboard; you must explain it better.
Why he teaches it: It forces high-bandwidth communication and ensures the Navigator stays engaged, fixing the common problem where the Navigator “zones out.”



2. The Dojo Master: Emily Bache
Emily Bache is arguably the world’s leading expert on Technical Coaching and Coding Dojos. She wrote the book The Coding Dojo Handbook and popularized the famous “Gilded Rose” refactoring kata.

The “Samman” Method: She developed the Samman Technical Coaching method, where a coach works with a team in two modes:

Learning Hour: Practicing safe, small exercises (Katas) away from production code.
The Ensemble: Working on the actual production code as a group (Mob Programming) to apply the new skills immediately.

Why she matters: She focuses on “Ensemble Programming” (Mob Programming) as the primary way to teach TDD, arguing that learning is faster when the whole team learns together rather than in isolated pairs.



3. The Craftsman: Sandro Mancuso
Sandro Mancuso founded the Software Craftsmanship movement in London and wrote The Software Craftsman. He teaches that TDD and Pairing are not just “Agile tricks” but ethical obligations of a professional.

His Focus: He focuses on Professionalism. He teaches that writing “dirty code” is unprofessional in the same way a surgeon leaving tools inside a patient is unprofessional.
The “Bank Kata”: He frequently uses a “Bank Kata” to teach “Outside-In TDD” (or London School TDD), where you start with the high-level API and use “Mock Objects” to design the system top-down, pairing closely to define interfaces before implementation.



4. The Philosopher: J.B. Rainsberger
J.B. (famous for “J.B.rains”) is a coach who focuses heavily on the psychology and design aspects of TDD.

His Mantra: “TDD is a design technique, not a testing technique.”
The Lesson: He teaches that if TDD is painful, your design is bad. He uses pairing sessions to show developers that their “hard to test” code is actually “highly coupled” code. He helps teams realize that the pain they feel when pairing or testing is a signal to refactor the architecture, not to stop testing.



5. The Mob Evangelist: Woody Zuill
While Llewellyn Falco formalized the “Strong Style” of pairing, Woody Zuill took it to the extreme by popularizing Mob Programming (now often called Software Teaming or Ensemble Programming).

The “Turn Up The Good” Philosophy: He noticed that when his team fixed bugs together on one screen, they were faster and happier. So he asked, “If this is good, why don’t we turn up the good?” and they started working on everything together, all day, every day.
His Coaching Style: He is famous for a very gentle, humane approach. He focuses on kindness, consideration, and respect in the pairing/mobbing environment, proving that psychological safety is the precursor to technical excellence.

title: Top, but Toxic performers

title: Top, but Toxic performers
section: P: What research is available on the impact of excellent but toxic/egoistic on team/org performance?
text:
P: What research is available on the impact of excellent but toxic/egoistic on team/org performance?
Research indicates that while “brilliant jerks” (often called toxic high performers) may deliver short-term individual results, their net impact on an organization is almost universally negative.
The following analysis details the key research findings on how these individuals affect team dynamics and organizational behavior.

1. The Economic Case: Cost vs. Benefit
The most direct research challenges the assumption that high output justifies bad behavior.
The “Toxic Worker” Study (Harvard Business School): A study of nearly 60,000 workers by Dylan Minor and Michael Housman found that avoiding a toxic employee is worth twice as much as hiring a superstar.
The Math: Hiring a top 1% performer adds roughly $5,300 in productivity gains. However, avoiding a toxic worker saves approximately $12,500 in turnover and replacement costs.
Conclusion: It is more profitable to avoid toxicity than to chase brilliance.


2. The “Bad Apple” Effect on Teams
Research confirms that toxicity is contagious and disproportionately damaging to group performance.
The 30–40% Drop (University of Washington/Rotterdam School of Management): Researcher Will Felps conducted a study placing “bad apples” (actors playing roles like “The Jerk,” “The Slacker,” or “The Depressive”) into teams.
Finding: Teams with just one toxic member saw their performance drop by 30% to 40%.
Mechanism: The toxic behavior didn’t just isolate the “jerk”—it spread. Teammates naturally began to mimic the bad behavior, reduce their own effort, and squabble amongst themselves (“emotional contagion”).


3. The “Competent Jerk” Dilemma
A seminal framework in organizational psychology explains why these people survive in companies despite the damage they cause.
Casciaro & Lobo (Harvard Business Review): In their study “Competent Jerks, Lovable Fools”, they classified employees by Competence and Likability.
The finding: When forced to choose, most people prefer the “Lovable Fool” (low competence, high likability) over the “Competent Jerk” (high competence, low likability).
The trap: However, managers often protect Competent Jerks because their individual metrics look good on paper. This creates a disconnect where leadership values the jerk, but the team (who relies on trust and collaboration) is actively sabotaged by them.


4. Psychological Impact & Narcissism
High performers with toxic traits often display “rivalrous narcissism,” which is distinct from confident.
Admirative vs. Rivalrous Narcissism: Research distinguishes between narcissists who want to be admired (often charismatic and initially effective) and those who are rivalrous (see others as threats).
Impact: Rivalrous high performers actively suppress team cohesion. They hoard information, steal credit, and create “psychological danger,” stopping others from speaking up or innovating.
Moral Disengagement: These individuals often use their high performance as a moral license (“I made the most sales, so I can yell at the support staff”), which normalizes abuse within the culture.


5. Organizational Long-Term Consequences
The research highlights three specific long-term damages:

Asymmetric Turnover: You don’t just lose employees; you lose your best employees. High performers have the most options in the job market and are the least tolerant of toxic peers. They leave; the mediocre employees (who can’t leave) stay and tolerate the abuse.
Innovation Stagnation: Psychological safety is the #1 predictor of effective teams (Google’s Project Aristotle. Toxic high performers destroy this safety, silencing the debate and risk-taking required for innovation.
Managerial Credibility: When leaders tolerate a toxic high performer, they signal that “values” are just marketing. This cynicism reduces engagement across the entire organization.

title: Team Topologies
section: P: Please give me a summary of Team Topologies: Organizing Business and Technology Teams for Fast Flow Book by Manuel Pais and Matthew Skelton.
text:
P: Please give me a summary of Team Topologies: Organizing Business and Technology Teams for Fast Flow Book by Manuel Pais and Matthew Skelton.
Here’s a summary of the book Team Topologies: Organizing Business and Technology Teams for Fast Flow by Manuel Pais and Matthew Skelton.
The book provides a practical and adaptive model for organizing technology and business teams. Its primary goal is to help organizations achieve a fast flow of software delivery by optimizing team structures to reduce dependencies, improve communication, and, most importantly, manage team cognitive load.

The Core Problem: Cognitive Load
The central concept of the book is Team Cognitive Load. This refers to the total amount of mental effort a team is using at any given time. The authors, drawing on psychologist John Sweller’s work, argue that a team, like an individual, has a finite cognitive capacity.
If a team is responsible for too many different things (e.g., multiple complex business domains, intricate infrastructure, testing, operations, and user support), its cognitive load becomes too high. This overload is the main blocker to a fast flow of value, leading to:

Slow delivery
Poor-quality work
Team burnout
An inability to innovate

The entire Team Topologies model is designed to explicitly limit and manage the cognitive load of each team.


The Four Fundamental Team Topologies
The book proposes that instead of functional silos (like “dev,” “ops,” “QA”), organizations should use only four fundamental types of teams.

Stream-aligned Team: This is the primary team type. It’s a cross-functional team aligned to a single, valuable “stream” of work, such as a product, a service, a user journey, or a specific business capability. They are empowered to build, run, and own their service end-to-end, from idea to production and back. The majority of teams in an organization should be stream-aligned.
Platform Team: The purpose of a platform team is to enable stream-aligned teams to deliver their work with more autonomy and less effort. They provide internal services and tools (e.g., CI/CD pipelines, monitoring dashboards, self-service infrastructure) as an internal “product.” This reduces the cognitive load on stream-aligned teams, as they don’t have to be experts in (for example) Kubernetes orchestration.
Enabling Team: This is a team of specialists (e.g., in security, test automation, or a new technology) who help stream-aligned teams acquire missing capabilities. Their goal is not to do the work for other teams but to “teach them how to fish.” They are temporary and move on once the stream-aligned team is self-sufficient in that area.
Complicated-subsystem Team: This team is only created when a specific part of the system is so complex that it requires deep, specialized knowledge (e.g., a real-time video processing engine, a complex financial-modeling algorithm). This team builds and maintains that one subsystem, hiding its complexity from other teams (usually platform or stream-aligned) who consume it as a service.



The Three Team Interaction Modes
The book also defines three specific ways these teams should interact. Using these explicit modes makes communication and dependencies clear, avoiding messy, undefined “coordination.”

Collaboration: Two teams work closely together for a defined, temporary period. This mode is used for rapid discovery and innovation, such as when a stream-aligned team and a platform team are figuring out a new API. It is high-bandwidth but creates a high cognitive load, so it should be used sparingly and with a clear goal.
X-as-a-Service: This is the most common and desirable mode. One team consumes a service, tool, or API from another (like a platform team) with minimal interaction. This mode works best when the service is reliable, well-documented, and easy to use, as it minimizes the cognitive load on the consuming team.
Facilitating: One team (usually an enabling team) helps and mentors another team to clear an obstacle or learn a new skill. The goal is to grow the capabilities of the team being facilitated. This is a temporary interaction.



Key Principles and Goals

Fast Flow: The ultimate goal is to optimize the organization for a fast, smooth flow of change into production. The topologies and interaction modes are all in service of this goal.
Reverse Conway’s Law: The book heavily references Conway’s Law, which states that organizations design systems that mirror their own communication structures. Team Topologies advises organizations to use this as a tool: “First, design the organization you want, and the system architecture will follow.” By creating small, autonomous, stream-aligned teams, you are intentionally designing your organization to produce a loosely coupled, modular software architecture.
Team-First Approach: The team is the fundamental unit of delivery. The model emphasizes creating long-lived, stable teams and giving them the autonomy and cognitive space to own their work and “build the right thing” and “build the thing right.”

title: Team Topologies
section: P: How is ‘team cognitive load’ defined in the book?
text:
P: How is ‘team cognitive load’ defined in the book?
In Team Topologies, ‘team cognitive load’ is defined as the total mental effort and capacity being used by a team at any given time to get their work done.
The authors, Manuel Pais and Matthew Skelton, adapt this concept from psychologist John Sweller’s Cognitive Load Theory. They argue that a team, just like an individual, has a finite mental capacity. If a team is responsible for too much, their performance plummets.
The book breaks this load down into three specific types:

Intrinsic Cognitive Load: The “good” or necessary complexity related to the team’s core domain. For example, the effort required to understand the specific business rules of a payment processing system.
Extraneous Cognitive Load: The “bad” or wasteful complexity. This is the mental effort spent on non-value-adding tasks, such as fighting with deployment tools, navigating complex environments, or trying to understand another team’s confusing API.
Germane Cognitive Load: The “value-adding” complexity. This is the effort dedicated to learning, improving, and innovating within the core domain, such as discovering better ways to solve a business problem or improving the system’s architecture.

The central goal of the Team Topologies model is to minimize extraneous cognitive load (by using things like Platform teams) and keep the intrinsic load manageable. This frees up the team’s mental capacity for the germane load, which is where true innovation and “fast flow” happen.

title: Team Topologies

My thoughts
So, “team topologies” are basically advocating for component teams, teams that are narrowly specialized in either business (value-streams) or technology domains, and effort must be made to ensure they are as independent as possible, as few dependencies as possible; i.e teams work in isolation. They recognize the value of cross-functionality within the team, but reject the same idea for several teams working in the same product area.

Deconstruct the skill

The major barrier to skill acquisition isn’t intellectual, it’s emotional.
Overcome the resistance to learn a new skill (initial excitement and realization of the difficulty).

Focus of few topics
Set concrete performance targets
Make sure you have necessary tools
General overview -> Divide into subtopics
Learn in short bursts (< 1h)
Fast feedback
Active recall

Examples:
Programming

I spent some time learning what “programming” and “web applications” are in general,    then deconstructed these skills into smaller sub-skills that are easier to understand and practice.
I set my target performance level by choosing two specific projects I wanted to create,    then defined what those projects would look like when finished.
I deconstructed those projects into smaller sub-steps then identified which sub-steps seemed    most important.
I made sure I had the tools I needed to work (like the latest version of Ruby),    and that I was able to find and use any additional tools I needed.
I found a few reliable sources of programming information, but I skipped canned tutorials    in favor of jumping in and writing the actual programs.
I worked on the most important sub-steps first, like figuring out how to test programs    on my computer, push the finished application to production, etc.
I used reference examples to get started and build confidence, then tested various approaches    to figure out how to program the features I wanted.
When I made an error, the program crashed and gave me an error message,    creating a fast feedback loop.
After getting an error, I experimented with several ways to fix it.    If I couldn’t fix the problem myself, I searched for help.
I kept using the build / test / fix approach until my programs were complete.

Touch typing

I learned how to change my keyboard layout to Colemak.
I created a fast feedback loop by rearranging the physical keys on the keyboard, so if I forgot  where a character was located, I could find it easily.
I used the Keyzen typing tutor to learn the placement of characters by touch, learning the most-used characters first. Keyzen re-introduced characters to the training set as I made mistakes, so I spent most of my time practicing difficult characters until my accuracy improved. I practiced for 45 minutes every night, just before going to bed, so my brain could consolidate the motor skills into long-term memory most effectively.
Once I got to functional speed (20 WPM), I switched to Type-Fu, focusing on typing sentences as fast as possible with over 99% accuracy.
When I reached 40 WPM, I used Amphetype to train the most common English bigrams and trigrams, further increasing my speed and accuracy.
Once I mastered the n-gram set, I switched to training the most common English words in Amphetype until I reached 60 WPM sustained with 99% accuracy, which happened at the 21 hour mark.

title: LLM and code quality
text:
Here’s a structured breakdown of how using large language models (LLMs) for coding can influence code quality – both beneficial effects and risks – based on recent studies and empirical evidence.


Before diving in, it’s helpful to clarify what we mean by code quality. Common (but not exhaustive) dimensions include:

Functional correctness (the code does what it’s supposed to do)
Readability / maintainability (clear structure, naming, documentation)
Reliability / robustness (handles edge cases, errors, unexpected inputs)
Performance / efficiency (reasonable resource use)
Security / absence of vulnerabilities
Adherence to architectural and style constraints / consistency

An LLM-based coding assist can affect each of these in different ways.



Here are mechanisms by which LLMs (e.g. Copilot, Code Llama, ChatGPT, etc.) may enhance quality, along with supporting evidence.

Reducing boilerplate / mechanical errors


LLMs excel at generating repetitive code patterns (e.g. CRUD routines, input validation, serialization). By automating mundane code scaffolding, they reduce opportunities for human typo or boilerplate mistakes, letting the human focus on logic and design.
In empirical experiments, Copilot-assisted developers had a 53.2% greater chance of passing all unit tests in a controlled task (versus those without it) — indicating an increase in functional correctness at least in that context. ￼
Similarly, GitHub’s internal “Quantifying Copilot” study found gains in readability, reliability, maintainability, and conciseness (though modest in magnitude) for Copilot-assisted code.


Improving readability / consistency


Because LLMs have seen a vast corpus of code, they often generate code that follows common idioms and stylistic patterns. This can produce more consistent naming, formatting, and structural patterns.
In code review assessments from the Copilot experiments, code written with Copilot had fewer readability errors in blind review, on average.
Beyond code generation, LLMs are also being used to revise code quality issues (e.g. take an input source and propose refactoring or fixes). For example, Microsoft’s “CORE” system uses a proposer + ranker LLM framework to suggest revisions based on static analysis outputs, thereby resolving code quality issues.


Faster iteration, freeing cognitive bandwidth


With LLMs handling trivial or repetitive parts, developers can devote more attention to higher-level design, edge-case handling, and architecture — tasks that more strongly affect long-term code quality.
GitHub’s Copilot telemetry/usage studies show that developers report lower mental fatigue, faster completion times, and happier workflows with Copilot assistance.
In enterprise settings (e.g. Accenture), adoption of Copilot corresponded with more pull requests and higher merge rates (which implies fewer blockers in code review) — suggesting that code written with AI help still met quality gates.


Discovering non-local patterns / detecting anti-patterns


LLMs (especially large ones) can “see” across code context (within their context window) and suggest refactoring or warn about patterns that are not locally obvious (e.g. suggesting a shared helper, factoring duplicated logic, etc.).
More broadly, reviews of LLMs applied to source code highlight their strength in recognizing structural patterns and correlations that might escape a human glancing at only a few files.


Augmenting or automating code review / linting / static-analysis


LLMs are being integrated into code review pipelines, providing inline suggestions or catching issues before human review. This can reduce the backlog of simple review feedback and allow human reviewers to focus on architectural/semantic matters.
They are also used to generate or repair tests, suggest documentation, and enforce consistency constraints.




While LLMs have promise, they are not magic, and can degrade quality (or induce new classes of defects) if used carelessly.

Code smells and architectural debt


The latest work “Investigating the Smells of LLM Generated Code” (2025) finds that LLM-generated code exhibits substantially more code smells compared to human-written reference code. On average, the smell rate increased by ~63% (across various complexity levels).
Smells include both implementation smells (e.g. duplicated logic, long methods) and design smells (e.g. poor modularization) — particularly in more complex tasks or advanced object-oriented designs.
Because LLMs are pattern-based, they may favor more “local” fixes rather than holistic refactoring. Over time, this can accumulate technical debt, lower consistency across modules, or hamper maintainability.


Security vulnerabilities


In empirical audits, Security Weaknesses of Copilot-Generated Code in GitHub Projects found that a nontrivial portion of LLM-generated snippets contain security flaws. Specifically, 29.5% of Python and 24.2% of JavaScript snippets exhibited at least one weakness according to CWE metrics.
Common weakness classes included use of insufficient randomness, code injection, cross-site scripting, and improper control of generated code.
On the mitigation side, combining static analyzers with LLM-based fixes (via Copilot Chat prompts) could remediate up to ~55.5% of those flagged vulnerabilities in some experiments.


Overconfidence, complacency, and human error propagation


Because the model seems “smart,” there is a risk developers might over-trust suggestions and insufficiently vet them, especially in less familiar domains or critical code (e.g. security, concurrency, performance-sensitive code).
In educational settings, a recent controlled study with undergraduates found that Copilot use can lead to over reliance and superficial understanding (i.e. students accept suggestions without fully reasoning about them).
The same study noted that while task completion time decreased, there were subtle regressions in learning and debugging skills.


Context / domain mismatch, hallucinations, stale knowledge


LLMs are trained on large corpora, but may not reflect your specific project’s architecture, domain logic, or constraints. A suggestion might violate invariants or assumptions not visible to the model.
Hallucinated code (i.e. syntactically plausible but semantically incorrect) is still a well-known risk.
For domain-specific or cutting-edge code (e.g. new libraries, novel algorithms), the LLM’s training may not fully cover the space, leading to weak suggestions or misleading completions.


Fragmentation / consistency drift


Over time, different parts of the codebase might get generated or touched with different “flavors” of LLM suggestions, introducing inconsistent patterns, naming conventions, or architectural styles, unless there is strict oversight and linting.
Some developers report that LLMs are weaker at refactoring and maintaining cohesive architecture in large codebases. “LLMs make it easy to write code, but aren’t as good at refactoring and maintaining a cohesive architecture.”


Downward pressure on quality in large codebases


Some commentary and analyses (e.g. “Downward Pressure on Code Quality” articles) warn that faster coding enabled by LLMs might tempt teams to accept more “quick and dirty” changes, deferring refactoring and increasing technical debt over time.
These arguments are more cautionary than definitive; the effect likely depends on team discipline, reviews, and development culture.


Effect on maintainers / on-boarding / future edits


If generated code is opaque or non‐idiomatic, future maintainers may struggle to understand, debug, or extend it — especially if the LLM suggestion lacks comments, rationale, or clear logic.
The “explainability” of LLM output is limited; often not accompanied by reasoning or formal guarantees, making review more difficult.




Given the dual nature of benefits and risks, the net effect of LLM use on code quality depends heavily on how it’s integrated into the development process. Some key moderating factors:

Developer skill and domain knowledge


Strong developers are more capable of vetting, refining, and adapting LLM suggestions; they can correct mistakes or steer the model. Novice users may blindly accept suboptimal output.
For well-known patterns, LLMs can be very helpful; for novel or domain-specific components, human insight is still critical.


Review / quality gates


Rigorous code review, static analysis, testing, and security audits must remain — LLM usage should not replace these quality safeguards, but augment them.
A good strategy is to treat LLM-generated code as a first draft to be improved, rather than a final deliverable.


Prompt design / context provision


Better prompts (with overviews, constraints, tests, style guides) lead to better suggestions. The LLM must “know” your expectations and context.
Where possible, giving the model feedback (e.g. “fix this,” “make this more modular,” etc.) can steer it toward higher-quality code.


Incremental adoption and monitoring


Gradual adoption lets teams monitor metrics (defects, review comments, churn, security bugs) and detect regressions early.
Some organizations perform their own A/B or causal analyses to isolate the effect of the LLM on quality (as seen in Faros’ analysis of Copilot usage).


Specialization & dividing tasks


Use LLMs for tasks where they shine (scaffolding, boilerplate, test generation, simple functions) while retaining human control over architecture, core business logic, security/critical paths, and system integration.


Continuous improvement / retraining


Capturing patterns of accepted suggestions, feedback loops (i.e. learning from corrections), and internal fine-tuning can improve future suggestions to better align with project style and domain constraints.





Net effect is neither guaranteed positive nor negative — using LLMs can improve code quality (especially in functional correctness, readability, and iteration speed) if used thoughtfully, but also introduces additional risk vectors (smells, security flaws, architectural drift, over reliance).
Empirical and controlled studies suggest modest but statistically significant improvements in many quality dimensions for LLM-assisted coding under experimental conditions. ￼
But emerging research (e.g. on code smells) is raising caution flags about the quality of generated code, particularly in complex scenarios.
The key is governance: strong review processes, prompt engineering, domain expertise, and monitoring are essential to ensuring LLM use leads to net quality gains.

text:
The verified casualty figures for the current Ukrainian-Russian war indicate extremely high losses on both sides, with substantial military and civilian deaths and injuries reported throughout 2025. The estimates below reflect the most current numbers from reputable organizations and official statements.



As of mid-November 2025, Russia has sustained between 226,000 and 327,000 confirmed military deaths, based on BBC analysis of Russian servicemen and contractors only 12.
The total Russian casualties (killed, wounded, missing), according to UK Defense Intelligence and ISW reports from October 2025, exceed 1.1 million since the full-scale invasion began, with 332,000 casualties reported just in 2025 3.
Ukrainian military intelligence estimates 86,744 Russian soldiers killed and 33,996 missing in the first eight months of 2025 4.
Russia continues to experience over 1,000 daily casualties in the later months of 2025 5.





Ukraine confirmed 43,000 military deaths as of December 2024, though Western analysts believe this is likely an undercount 6.
As of October 2025, projects cross-referencing Ukrainian military fatalities have documented 79,213 Ukrainian fighters killed by name and 81,728 missing in action, totaling 160,941 dead or missing 7.
Estimates from Western sources place Ukrainian losses between 60,000 and 100,000 killed and up to 400,000 wounded 8.
President Zelenskyy stated in February 2025 that over 46,000 Ukrainians had been killed and 380,000 wounded since the war began 9.





The United Nations verified at least 13,883 civilian deaths and 35,548 injuries since the start of the full-scale invasion 1011.
Monthly civilian casualties in 2025 were significantly higher than in 2024, with July 2025 marking the highest death toll since May 2022 12.
Civilian death tolls surpassed 13,800 by July 2025, according to OHCHR 13.

Compared to the Ukrainian-Russian war, the USSR-Afghanistan conflict saw significantly fewer Soviet military deaths but far greater Afghan civilian casualties and destruction over a decade (1979–1989) 25262728.

Soviet-Afghan War Casualties

Soviet military deaths: Around 13,310–15,000 over 10 years 293031.
Soviet wounded: About 35,478–53,753 3233.
Missing Soviet soldiers: 311–312 3435.
Afghan civilians killed: Estimates range from 562,000 up to 2,000,000; most historians cite about 1 million 36373839.
Afghan military killed: Between 75,000 and 90,000 (mujahedeen) and about 58,000 pro-communist forces 404142.
Total displaced: Over 5 million Afghans became refugees, and 3 million were internally displaced 4344.

title: The story behind WD-40
text: Recently I’ve heard an interesting story about WD-40.

title: The story behind WD-40
section: P: Do you know the story behind the product called WD-40?
text:
P: Do you know the story behind the product called WD-40?
The story of WD-40 is a classic example of persistence and accidental success. It wasn’t originally designed for squeaky doors or stuck zippers; it was invented for rocket science
Here is the breakdown of how “Water Displacement, 40th Formula” came to be.

1. The Original Purpose: Protecting Missiles
In 1953, a small company called the Rocket Chemical Company in San Diego, California, set out to create a line of rust-prevention solvents and degreasers for the aerospace industry.
Their specific goal was to create a formula that would displace water to prevent corrosion on the outer skin of the Atlas Missile (the first operational intercontinental ballistic missile developed for the U.S. Air Force). The missile’s stainless steel skin was so thin that it was actually kept rigid by the pressure of the fuel inside; if it rusted or corroded, it could be catastrophic.


2. The Name: Why “40”?
The name is surprisingly literal. It stands for “Water Displacement, 40th Formula.”
The chemists at the company (often credited to Norm Larsen, though some sources cite chemist Iver Norman Lawson) worked through 39 failed formulas. They were trying to find a chemical balance that would effectively displace standing water and prevent moisture from forming.
On their 40th attempt, they finally got the mixture right. That is the exact formula still in use today.


3. From Rockets to Household Shelves
The transition from industrial aerospace product to household staple happened organically:

The “Sneak” Phase: The product worked so well at the plant that employees started sneaking cans of it home in their lunchboxes to use on their own cars, tools, and squeaky appliances.
The Pivot: Noticing this unauthorized personal use, Norm Larsen realized the commercial potential. In 1958, the company began putting the fluid into aerosol cans and selling it to the general public in San Diego.
The Big Break: In 1961, a massive storm called Hurricane Carla struck the U.S. Gulf Coast. The company received its first truckload order to ship WD-40 to the victims, who used it to recondition flood-damaged vehicles and equipment. This proved its utility on a massive scale.



4. Interesting Facts
The Secret Sauce: The formula is a trade secret and was never patented. This was a strategic move; patents require you to publicly disclose your ingredients, and patents eventually expire. By keeping it a trade secret, the company never had to reveal exactly what is in the can.
Not a Lubricant? Technically, WD-40 is a solvent and a water displacer, not a primary lubricant. While it helps things move by cleaning them and unsticking them, it eventually evaporates. (For long-term lubrication, you are often better off with silicone or grease).
The Company Name: The Rocket Chemical Company was so successful with this one product that they eventually just renamed the entire company. In 1969, they officially became the WD-40 Company.

title: Bionic Reading
text: Here’s a detailed breakdown of the reading‑method called Bionic Reading—how it works, what claims are made, and what the empirical evidence (to date) suggests. I’ve also included comments on how the method aligns (or doesn’t) with known cognitive/ocular‑neuroscience of reading.

title: Bionic Reading
text: Here’s a detailed breakdown of the reading‑method called Bionic Reading—how it works, what claims are made, and what the empirical evidence (to date) suggests. I’ve also included comments on how the method aligns (or doesn’t) with known cognitive/ocular‑neuroscience of reading.

title: Bionic Reading
text:
What is Bionic Reading?
Definition & mechanism
- Bionic Reading was developed by Swiss designer Renato Casutt. According to his website, the idea is to “make reading easier by guiding the eyes through artificial fixation points”. (howtogeek.com)
- In practice: parts of words (typically the first few letters) are bolded (or otherwise visually highlighted). The idea is that the reader’s eye jumps (“saccades”) from one bolded section (“fixation point”) to the next, and the brain fills in the remainder of each word. (triangle.indwes.edu)
- Additional parameters: the method’s website refers to three components—Fixation, Saccade, and Opacity—which allow adjustments (how many letters are bolded, how visible the non‑bold text is, column width, etc.). (bionic-reading.com)
- It is marketed as a tool for reading speed, reading focus (especially for those with attentional issues), and improved comprehension/retention. For example the official site claims benefits such as “Save precious time. Gain advantages. Learn new things faster.” (bionic-reading.com)
Practical usage
- Apps or browser extensions exist to convert regular text (PDF, EPUB, web pages) into Bionic Reading format. (howtogeek.com)
- Users report that for them the bolded‑first‑letters help them focus and “skim” more easily, though this is anecdotal. (See for instance Reddit commentary.) (reddit.com)

title: Bionic Reading
text:
What claims are made?
Key claims include:

Increased reading speed (because eye‑movement/fixation is reduced).

Improved comprehension (because brain fills in the rest of each word, supposedly reducing cognitive load).

Better focus / less distraction (especially for readers with ADHD, dyslexia, or low motivation).

Increased reading motivation, self‑efficacy (particularly in educational settings). (ijams-bbp.net)

So in short: Bionic Reading is pitched as an accessibility/efficiency tool for reading.

title: Bionic Reading
section: What does the scientific evidence say?
text:
What does the scientific evidence say?
Since you have a scientific background, I’ll divide into (A) rigorous experimental/empirical studies, and (B) smaller scale educational/qualitative studies, followed by my commentary.

A. Rigorous empirical studies

A peer‑reviewed article listed on PubMed:
Title: “No, Bionic Reading does not work” (Elsevier, 2024) – statistical analyses for 100 paragraphs comparing Bionic vs normal reading found no significant difference in reading times. (pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov)
The authors conclude: “I conclude that Bionic Reading does not facilitate reading.” (pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov)

An EEG master’s thesis: “An EEG Study on The Effect of Bionic Reading on Semantic Processing” (student thesis at Utrecht University) – this suggests an attempt to measure neural/semantic processing of Bionic Reading, but being a thesis (not full peer‑reviewed yet) limits its weight. (studenttheses.uu.nl)

Thus from the highest standard evidence so far: no robust effect on speed/efficiency in normal reading tasks.


B. Educational/qualitative studies

A quasi‑experimental study of 110 learners with learning disabilities in the Philippines (2022‑23) found that Bionic Reading improved reading motivation and self‑efficacy significantly for the experimental group (versus control) in post‑intervention tests. (ijams-bbp.net)

A classroom action research study (30 10th‑grade students, Indonesia) found average reading scores improved from 67 → 72 and % of students meeting a “minimum mastery criterion” increased from 63% → 75% using a “Bionic method”. (bajangjournal.com)

Some blog/educator commentary analyses are skeptical. For example, one article discusses five key questions and essentially points out that rigorous empirical evidence is lacking. (languageeducatorsassemble.com)



C. Summary of evidence

Reading speed/comprehension (normal adult readers): empirically no convincing benefit (per Elsevier study)

Motivation/self‑efficacy (learners with disabilities): some positive preliminary results

Overall: the method is not yet strongly validated in robust cognitive/behavioral studies.

title: Bionic Reading
text:
Critical commentary (given your background)
From a cognitive/neurological perspective:

Reading involves a complex interplay of bottom‑up (orthographic/phonological/lexical) processing and top‑down (semantic/contextual) processing. The “visual word form area”, saccadic eye‑movements, fixation durations, etc., all matter. For instance, research shows that altering text layout can affect oculomotor behaviour (see e.g., inverted/mirrored text reading) but tends to slow reading rather than speed it. (arxiv.org)

The claim of “brain fills in the rest of each word” relies on the assumption that readers consistently use a chunking strategy of few letters + context. While partial word recognition is plausible (there’s evidence for parafoveal processing, etc.), constructing artificial bolded fixation points presumes that you can systematically reduce fixations without increasing processing cost elsewhere (e.g., reconstructing the word, losing some letters, etc.).

The empirical null result (no significant difference in reading time) aligns with the expectation that any alteration in text format that changes typical fixations/saccades may disrupt rather than enhance reading in skilled readers.

The positive results in motivation/self‑efficacy settings (learners with disabilities) might reflect meta-cognitive/affective benefits (i.e., the novelty or perceived “helpful” formatting leads to increased engagement) rather than a true cognitive/processing speed increase.

Because you work in brain imaging, it is worth noting that I found no published neuroimaging study (fMRI/EEG) at large scale showing altered activation patterns or reading‑network efficiency changes due to Bionic Reading. The EEG thesis suggests someone is attempting that, but results don’t appear peer‑reviewed yet.

Speed‑reading claims (especially big ones) are generally treated with scepticism in reading‑science (see for example reviews of speed‑reading techniques). (en.wikipedia.org)

title: Bionic Reading
text:
My conclusion

At this point, the method is interesting, and the user‑reports (especially for dyslexia/attention issues) suggest that there may be some subjective benefit (engagement, focus).

However, if the question is “Does Bionic Reading improve reading speed/comprehension in adult readers under controlled conditions?” — the answer is: no strong evidence yet.

If you are considering either (a) recommending it for your own reading workflows, or (b) studying it as part of cognitive/neuroscience research, the key caveats are:

It may not help (and might even slow) skilled readers.

For reading‑disability populations the affective/motivational benefits might be worthwhile to explore further.

If you’re considering research: designing an eye‑tracking + EEG/fMRI study comparing normal vs bolded‑format reading (with conditions controlling for word‑length, frequency, fixation/saccade patterns) would be valuable.

The metric of “reading speed” should be carefully defined (words per minute, fixation count, saccade length) and “comprehension” needs to be tested with valid comprehension tasks, not just subject ratings.

title: Elevator Control Algorithm
text:
Short answer: for a small mid-rise (2 cars, 10 floors), a competent engineer can build a good dispatcher with standard heuristics; building a provably optimal or generally state-of-the-art controller is a hard stochastic control problem that researchers still publish on.



It’s a stochastic, multi-objective, multi-agent control problem. Arrivals vary by time (up-peak, lunch, down-peak), goals conflict (waiting time vs. ride time vs. energy), and decisions are coupled across cars. Classic work in RL framed elevator dispatching as a partially observable, non-stationary decision process.
Combinatorics explode. Even for 2×10: positions (10²), directions (3²), door states (2²), hall-call lamps (18 buttons → 2¹⁸), in-car buttons (2×10 → 2²⁰). Multiplying these gives ~9.9×10¹⁴ distinct (coarse) states – before modelling loads or travel times.
“Obvious” rules interact badly. Simple “nearest car” or even ETA-only dispatch can cause bunching and unfairness without extra logic (zoning, penalties, look-ahead). ￼





Collective control with ETA cost (a.k.a. “nearest/soonest car with smarts”): Assign each new hall call to the car that minimizes a cost like

\(J = w_{wait} \times \Delta(estimated\ wait) + w_{incar} \times \Delta(stops\ added) + w_{dir} \times (direction\ mismatch) + w_{load} \times (load\ factor)\)
with small look-ahead (simulate inserting the stop in each car’s queue). This, plus anti-bunching (small penalty if cars are within N floors) and simple peak-mode switches, yields robust performance in a small building. 2. Lightweight zoning/sectoring during peaks (e.g., car A favors floors 1–5, car B favors 6–10, but either can “steal” if much better). Helps fairness and reduces ping-ponging. 3. Destination control (DCS) (passengers key in floor before boarding) is often overkill for 2×10 but useful when traffic is bursty; it batches similar destinations and avoids unnecessary stops. Beware “reverse journeys” edge cases and good UI. ￼




Exact optimal control is intractable in practice due to the state/action explosion and uncertain arrivals. Research uses simulation optimization, multi-objective/meta-heuristics, and RL to beat hand-tuned heuristics—mostly on larger groups (e.g., 4+ cars, 15–40 floors).
Destination-dispatch assignment itself is a nontrivial combinatorial routing/assignment problem with time-dependent costs and constraints.





Traffic modes: up-peak, inter-floor, down-peak, off-peak; switch weights (w_wait, w_incar, w_dir) by mode (time-of-day + simple real-time triggers). ￼
Costed ETA assignment with 1–2 stop look-ahead, door-open/close timing and jerk-limited motion model.
Anti-bunching & parking: mild penalties when cars are close; when idle, park cars at strategic “home” floors (e.g., 3 and 8).
Fairness: cap maximum predicted wait; if exceeded, allow “stealing” across zones.
Diagnostics: log predicted vs. actual waits/ride times to tune weights.
(Optional) DCS kiosk prototype for peak-hour batching if your building can accept it.





Reinforcement learning: Crites & Barto showed RL can beat strong heuristics in simulation; modern variants continue to appear (but require careful state design and simulators).
Multi-objective optimization: explicitly balance average/percentile wait, ride time, and energy; evolutionary/submodular approaches exist.

text:
Primary sources to start from

Crites, R.H., & Barto, A.G. “Improving Elevator Performance Using Reinforcement Learning.” NeurIPS (1995/1996). Seminal RL treatment; clear statement of elevator-control challenges. ￼
Fernández, J.R., & Cortés, P. “A Survey of Elevator Group Control Systems for Vertical Transportation.” IEEE Control Systems Magazine 35(4), 2015. Authoritative survey of heuristics and advanced methods. ￼
Koehler, J., & Ottiger, D. “An AI-Based Approach to Destination Control in Elevators.” AI Magazine 23(3), 2002. Classic DCS ideas and batching rationale. ￼
Ruokokoski, M., et al. “Assignment formulation for the Elevator Dispatching Problem in destination controls.” European Journal of Operational Research (2016). Formal assignment formulations. ￼
Peters Research note on dispatching heuristics (nearest car, ETA, bunching) — concise practitioner overview. ￼

Bottom line: For 2 cars and 10 floors, you can get very good service with a well-tuned ETA-based heuristic plus a dash of zoning and anti-bunching. The difficulty ramps up quickly if you chase theoretical optimality, add destination dispatch, or require strong guarantees across all traffic regimes – which is why it remains an active research area.

text:
Socio-technical systems. Humans + computers. Complex systems are easier to hack.
Types of hacks: technical, economic, financial, legal, social, political, cognitive.
Hacking is exploiting a system without breaking the system’s rules but subverting rules’ intent for personal gain at the expense of the other participants in the system.
Good/useful hacks can be normalized (become part of the system) or patched. Non-technical hacks take years/generation to be patched.
Vulnerability and exploit.
Social hack: Administrative burden (make access to social benefits more difficult).
Hacks by AI systems: speed, scale, sophistication. Personalized, deep & subtle fakes.

title: How To Think More About Sex
text:
It is rare to get through this life without feeing that we are somehow a bit odd about sex.


Despite being one of the most private of activities, sex is nonetheless surrounded by a range of powerful socially sanctioned ideas that codify how normal people are meant to feel about and deal with the matter.


Whatever discomfort we de feel around sex is commonly aggravated by the idea that we belong to a liberated age – and ought by now, as a result, to be finding sex a straightforward and untroubling matter.

pre-religious society, religious society, 1920’s - 1960’s “sexual liberation”, bikinis, talk about masturbation and bdsm, watching pornography…

…sex is not something that we can ever expect to feel easily liberated from.

there is a reason why it was and still is a taboo subject in many social contexts.

it (sex) is a fundamentally disruptive, overwhelming and demented force, strongly at odds with the majority of our ambitions and all but incapable of being discreetly integrated within civilized society.


It refuses to sit neatly on top of love, as it should.

title: How To Think More About Sex
text:
1. Eroticism and Loneliness
Evolutionary biology, genetically programmed for reproduction, pleasures of sex as a reward for undertaking the immense efforts of raising children
But evolutionary biology doesn’t really provide us with a very satisfactory account of why sex should really matter to us as reflexive humans.
Memories of first or new encounter with someone exhibiting reciprocal interest, first kiss… Relation to child-mother, unconditional acceptance, tenderness and love with a lot of physical contact. Gradually there is a separation, covering of the body, adolescence, social and cultural norms, public and private self, shame.

We grow into clumsy, heavy-footed, shameful, anxious creatures. We become adults, definitively expelled from paradise. But deep inside, we never quite forget the needs with which we were born: to be accepted as we are, without regard to our deeds; to be loved through the medium of our body; to be enclosed in another’s arms.


The Kiss – Acceptance

It could sound disgusting, and that’s the point. Nothing is erotic that isn’t also, with the wrong person, revolting, which is precisely what makes erotic moments so intense.



The Undressing – An end to shame

The shame begins in adolescence… A division begins between our ordinary public selves on the one hand and our sexual and private identities on the other. A large portion of who we are as adults, from our sexual fantasies to our parted legs, becomes impossible to share with almost anyone we know.

sexual fantasies clash with what we think is proper and expected behavior (from family and society).


Excitement – Authenticity

Erections and lubrication simply cannot be effected by willpower and are therefore particularly true and honest indices of interest.



Rudeness – Love

It can be a sign of love to be allowed to slap someone hard across the face or to clasp our hands forcefully around another’s neck… It doesn’t matter to them (partner) that we have darker sides; they can – like the ideal parent – see us whole and recognize us as being fundamentally good.


When we are on the receiving end of this type of violence and rudeness, we may find a parallel pleasure, and a certain sense of strength, in being able to decide for ourselves just how insulted, hurt and dominated we are going to feel.



Fetishism – Goodness

We will be drawn to specific things either because they recall appealing qualities of a beloved parental figure or else, conversely, because they somehow cancel out, or otherwise help us to escape, a memory of early humiliation or terror.

Deep, semi-conscious memories that might indicate/confirm an ideal partner.

They turn us on because they are emblems of the Good.



Orgasm – Utopia

The more closely we analyze what we consider “sexy”, the more clearly we will understand that eroticism is the feeling of excitement we experience at finding another human being who shares our values and our sense of the meaning of existence.


The orgasm itself marks the supreme moment when our loneliness and alienation are momentarily overcome. Everything we have appreciated about our lover […] are combined into a concentrated distillation of pleasure that leaves each partner feeling uniquely tender towards and vulnerable with the other.


Post-coital sadness often settles over a couple.


…it [sex] is an ecstasy we feel at encountering someone who may be able to put to rest certain of our greatest fears, and with whom we may hope to build a shared life based upon common values.

We tend to tiptoe around what we want, cloaking our needs with evasions and in the process, we habitually lie, break others’ hearts and suffer through evenings filled with frustration and guilt.

Suffering sexual rejection by the person with whom we have pledged to share our life is a much odder and more humiliating experience.


…the paucity of sex within established relationships typically has to do with the difficulty of shifting registers between the everyday and the erotic.

Freud, child-parent love, taboo, children after marriage, mummy-daddy…

Safety. Will Felps, Uni of South Wales. Organizational behavior. Negative archetypes (jerk, slacker, downer) Impact of “bad apples” (by a good actor) leads to 30-40% of group performance drop. Highly successful groups are familial (“family”, “friends”), special chemistry. We can feel it and want to be part of it.
Human signaling. Alex Pentland, MIT Human Dynamics Lab. Sociometer (proximity, voice). Belonging cues. Much older than language. Answer the question: Are we safe together? Google vs Overture, AdWords engine, Jeff Dean. Constant flow of challanges in a safe group beats bigger and better funded group.

title: Why We Sleep
text:
3. Defining and Generating sleep
Polysomnography: 1) brainwave activity 2) eye movement activity 3) muscle activity.
REM and NREM sleep (1957), NREM has 4 stages. Humans go from wake to REM to NREM 1, 2, 3 and 4. Phase 3 and 4 are deep sleep (hardest to wake the person up). During the night we have 5-6 cycles of REM/NREM phases of ~1.5hrs. Duration of REM phase increases during later cycles.
Removing (pruning) of unnecessairy neural connections during the NREM, strengthening existing connections during REM. During REM, brain activity is very close to awake state (fast, no sync between regions). During NREM there are slow syncronized waves. Loss of consciousness and the sense of time during sleep is because of inhibition of sensory information flow through thalamus during sleep.
During NREM we transfer memories from short term to long term storage (reason why we need syncronization across regions).
Dreaming during REM is probably like a replay and check of memories after they have been modified during NREM phase. During REM phase the body is completely paralyzed (except for involuntary movement like breathing) again through thalamus to avoid motor activity due to dreaming (evolutionary, avoid dropping from trees while sleeping).

title: Why We Sleep
section: 4. Ape beds, dinosaurs, and napping with half a brain
text:
4. Ape beds, dinosaurs, and napping with half a brain
Every animal and bird species studied sleep including fish and insects. Even invertebrates like mollusks and worms have periods of slumber, i.e. sleep evolved during Cambrian explosion 500 mil years ago or wakefullness evolved from default sleep mode.
Huge variability of sleep duration and pattern across animals, from 4 to 19hrs/day. Size and complexity of the nervous system vs body mass have a weak correlation with sleep patterns. REM seems to exist only in mammals and birds. Aquatic animals (including mammals) don’t have REM sleep as we know it; pinnipeds (seals) have REM only when on land. Natural human sleep pattern is likely bi-phasic (like in siesta cultures): long night and short nap in the afternoon. MID-night.

Newborns spend lots of time sleeping (polyphasic sleep), progressively getting into bi-phasic (SCN development, after 3yo) and mono-phasic (after 6 yo).
Adolescents have their natural circadian cycle shift to later than adults, i.e. they can’t sleep early and wake up early.

Sleep after learning consolidates fact-based memory (during NREM sleep). Sleep also helps recover “lost” memories. Sleep also help to forget “unwanted” memories.

title: HR lingo
text:
language and the words you use say a lot about a culture, and that we can take steps to change culture through changing those words. – Emily Webber

The above quote is from a short and sweet “Should you call people resources?” post which resonated with me. I don’t remember when the term “resource” applied to people started to bother me. It’s been a while, but usually I didn’t do anything about it. Last year I decided to engage with an HR admin in a bank where I worked as an external consultant. She kept referring to me and my colleagues as “external resources” in emails. I’d asked her to stop calling us that, but either she had ignored my request or thought it wasn’t important and continued to call us “ER”s. I repeated my request accompanied by a small explanation why people are not resources thinking that sensible people especially working in HR would have no problem understanding it. Her reply: “but it is just a classification in our internal IT system”…
Some of my HR friends say that the R-word is slowly disappearing from their industry’s lexicon and that organization adopt Google’s “People Operation” or similar (hopefully not just borrowing the term and being done with it). I like this development.
What about “talent”? It is not as offensive as “resources”, but still might trigger “I’ve got no talents.” Or “I’m not good at this.” And isn’t talent overrated? And what about “human capital” or “human assets”? What is the benefit of using these words and constructs instead of just “people”?

title: Docker
text:
Docker commands
docker
    run $name[:$tag] [$cmd]
    ps [-a] [$name]
    stop $name | $id
    rm $name | $id
    images
    rmi $name
    pull $name
    attach $id
    logs $name


Docker run
docker run -it $name  # interactive + terminal
docker run -p 8008:80 $name  # daemon mode, link ports $host:$container
docker run -v /local/dir:/container/dir $name  # mount local volume
docker run -e MYVAR=foobar $name  # pass env var to container
NB: ports and volumes arguments always follow $host:$container order


Creating an image
cat > Dockerfile << EOF
FROM ubuntu
RUN apt-get update
RUN apt-get install python
RUN pip install flask flask-mysql
COPY . /opt/src
ENTRYPOINT FLASK_APP=/opt/src/app.py flask run
EOF
docker build . -t $myname
docker push $myname
docker history $myname  # to see layers (successful RUNs in Dockerfile)
Docker image is built from layers created from each FROM, RUN and COPY line. The layers are reused for different images.
Other useful commands: ENV, WORKDIR, USER, CMD


Network
By default docker uses bridge mode for containers running on the same host with default network 172.17.xxx.xxx. Other network modes are “none” (no network) and “host” (no network isolation from host).
docker network create --driver bridge --subnet 182.18.0.0/16 my_network
docker inspect $name will show full container info including network.
Dockers uses internal DNS 127.0.0.11 to resolve containers IP and containers names.


Storage
Containers, images, volumes are stored in /var/lib/docker. All image layers are RO. A contaier runs in a special RW container layer which gets destroyed when container is stoped. Data can be persisted in named volumes inside /var/lib/docker/volumes (volume mount) or a directory on a host (bind mount).
docker volume create my_volume
docker run -v my_volume:/var/log my_image

# new explicit format for mounting volumes
docker run --mount type=bind,source=/data/my_image/logs,target=/var/log my_image


Removing images
docker images
docker rmi <image_id1> <image_id2>
docker system prune -a
docker volume ls
docker volume rm <volume_name1> <volume_name2>


Docker compose
It’s possible to run multiple containers and “link” them for networking. But much easier to use docker-compose to manage multi-container app.
docker-compose.yml
version: 2

services:
  frontend:
    build:
      context: ./app
      args:
        DB_HOST: localhost:5005
    links:
      - db
    volumes:
      - logs:/var/logs
    depends_on:
      db:
        condition: service_started

  db:
    image: postgres:9.4
    ports:
      - "5005:5432"
    volumes:
      - /data/app/postgres:/var/lib/postgres

volumes:
  logs:
docker-compose up -d   #--build
docker-compose exec frontend ls -l
docker-compose logs frontend
docker-compose down -v

title: TDD katas for Data Scientists
text:
Whenever I talk about TDD to data science and data engineering folks, they say that either TDD is not working for algorithmic work, or I’ve tried FizzBuzz and it is not fun [^1]. I can understand. Most katas in places like kata-log are more oriented towards CS/SW devs.
So, I’ve decided to come up with some katas that might be more interesting for DS folks. Here they are.

title: TDD katas for Data Scientists
text:
ModPlus
ModPlus is a simple hashing algorithm. It takes in a positive integer X and returns a combinatorial sum of a binary representation of X after it is split into chunks of given length.
For example, modplus(12, chunk_length=3) should return 6.
Variation: ModPlusDot. Instead of combinatorial sum, use a combination of binary AND and OR when combining chunks.
Simple enough for an algorithmic problem. Skills to practice: splitting the problems into smaller problems, naming things, simplify by extraction, refactoring while in green, make it work first.
Practical application: Luhn algorithm.

title: TDD katas for Data Scientists
text:
2D vector
Imagine you are working for Khan Academy (KA). KA wants to modernize their basic math classes, especially the display. Implement a cartesian 2D Vector class, that supports scalar multiplication, addition with another Vector, norm (magnitude) and dot product between 2 vectors(see vector).
This is more of a design kata, but still requires to implement a couple of formulas.
